thread.title: Tory row ERUPTS after David Davis says EU labour needed for years after Brexit
thread.title_full: Tory row ERUPTS after David Davis says EU labour needed for years after Brexit

title: Tory row ERUPTS after David Davis says EU labour needed for years after Brexit
text:
But former Tory minister Iain Duncan Smith, a leading figure in the campaign to quit the EU, insisted home-grown workers could take over the migrant jobs on a much speedier timescale than that forecast by Mr Davis. 
Mr Duncan Smith said: "My sense is that it is going to happen quicker than that." 
And Ukip claimed the remarks showed that "uncontrolled immigration from the EU will continue after Brexit ". GETTY Iain Duncan Smith insisted British workers could quickly replace EU labour 
Mr Davis hinted at the Government's long-term border control plans while visiting Tallinn, the Estonian capital, on Tuesday. Tories can't be trusted to control our borders or immigration John Bickley of Ukip 
He said: "In the hospitality sector, hotels and restaurants, in the social care sector, working in agriculture, it will take time - it will be years and years before we get British citizens to do those jobs. 
"Don't expect just because we're changing who makes the decision on the policy, the door will suddenly shut: it won't." 
Mr Davis said migrants had helped make the UK a strong economy. GETTY The Brexit Secretary said that EU migrants helped give Britain a strong economy 
He said: "We're a successful economy, largely or partly at least because we have clever people, talented people come to Britain. 
"Even on the wider area, where we've got less well-paid people who have come to live and work in Britain, that will take time." 
His remarks are expected to provoke questions from some Leave supporters after Prime Minister Theresa May insisted that taking back control of immigration would be a key change after Brexit. 
John Bickley, Ukip's immigration spokesman, said: "David Davis has let the cat out of the bag by indicating that uncontrolled immigration from the EU will continue after Brexit. Remoaner-in-chief: Blair's Views on Brexit Fri, February 17, 2017
